misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student appears to understand the core concepts needed for this problem: array indexing, loop control flow, and variable assignment.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Upon careful analysis, this code demonstrates solid understanding of Java's execution model. The student correctly: (1) stores the last element in a temporary variable before overwriting, (2) shifts elements right by iterating backwards to avoid overwriting data, (3) places the saved element at index 0, and (4) properly formats output with spaces.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No errors - the code produces correct output matching the expected sample run.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when shifting array elements one position to the right, they must start moving elements from the end of the array (index n-1) back towards the beginning (index 1). This is done to prevent overwriting values before they are used in the shift operation.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: This belief is not a conceptual gap but an understanding of the mechanical requirement for properly shifting elements in an array. The student correctly identifies that moving elements from `y[i-1]` to `y[i]` must proceed from the highest index downwards to avoid losing data integrity. If they started from index 0, they would overwrite `y[1]` with `y[0]` before `y[0]` had a chance to move to `y[1]`, resulting in a duplication of the first element.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the last element of the array must be saved in a temporary variable before the shift operation begins. This temporary variable holds the value that will become the new first element after all other shifts are complete.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: This belief is entirely correct and demonstrates a proper understanding of state management when manipulating array elements in place. By saving `y[n-1]` in `t` (line 18), the value is preserved when `y[n-1]` is overwritten by `y[n-2]` during the backward traversal loop. Without this step, the wrap-around functionality would fail.
